tool.name: Analyze sequences for hypermutation

param.name: alignment
param.label: Sequence alignment on which to operate

param.name: context_selector
param.label: Hypermutation context
param.help: Specify analysis hypermutation pattern(s). Characters M, R and V correspond to IUPAC ambiguous nucleotide codes. For example, specifying GR looks for an elevation in combined G[G or A] → A[G or A] mutation rates over G[T or C] → A[T or C] mutation rates. (A sequence with low levels of APOBEC3G and APOBEC3F hypermutation might be GG and GA negative, but GR positive.)

param.name: sig_level
param.label: Significance level
param.help: If - with the specified confidence - G → A mutations in a hypermutation-associated context are more likely than G → A mutations in other contexts, the sequence will be marked as hypermutated.

param.name: reference_source_selector
param.label: Reference source
param.help: Each query sequence must have a reference sequence for comparison. For guidance choosing a reference sequence strategy, see https://github.com/fhcrc/hyperfreq/wiki/Reference-sequence-strategies.

param.name: ref_file
param.label: Sequence-to-cluster map
param.help: CSV file mapping sequences to clusters. Cluster consensus sequences will be used as query sequences. Sequences wihtout a cluster will be automatically put in a cluster named 'all'.

param.name: ref_file
param.label: Reference sequence(s)
param.help: FASTA file of reference sequences; Must be in alignment with query sequences, and sequence names should correspond to cluster names if using a cluster map. If not using a cluster map, ensure a sequence named 'all' is included in the alignment. Clusters for which no reference sequence is specified will be compared to a computed consensus sequence.

param.name: cluster_map
param.label: Sequence-to-cluster map
param.help: CSV file mapping sequences to clusters. Any sequences not mapped to a cluster will be implicitly put in an 'all' cluster.

param.name: cluster_threshold
param.label: Cluster threshold
param.help: Triggers the automated, hypermutation aware clustering (see wiki); Measured as the normalized Hamming distance between sequences.

param.name: min_per_cluster
param.label: Min number of sequences per cluster
param.help: Smaller clusters are merged with larger ones to avoid clusters composed mostly of hypermutated sequences. (Suggested: at least 2x+1, x being the maximum number of sequeces from any given specimen.)

configfiles.configfile:
ALIGNMENT="${alignment}" CONTEXTS="${context_selector}" SIG_LEVEL="${sig_level}"
#if $reference_source.reference_source_selector == "cluster" REFERENCE="-c $reference_source.ref_file" #else if $reference_source.reference_source_selector == "manual" REFERENCE="-r $reference_source.ref_file" #else REFERENCE="" #end if
CALLS="${calls}" SITES="${sites}" HM_POS_ALN="${hm_pos_aln}" HM_NEG_ALN="${hm_neg_aln}"

tool.help:
.. class:: infomark
What it does ------------
Hyperfreq is a APOBEC3-induced hypermutation analysis tool. It is context-based, analyzing whether G -> A mutations are more likely in contexts associated with APOBEC3 hypermutation than in other contexts (APOBEC3G for instance is more likely to mutate GG -> AG than G followed by anything other than G). While other tools take a similar approach, Hyperfreq uses Bayesian statistics, making it more sensitive, informative and flexible.
Considerations in choosing a Reference source ---------------------------------------------
As described above, each query sequence must be compared to a reference sequence. These references should be evolutionarily close to query sequences, while not exhibiting a hypermutation pattern. Hyperfreq comes bundled with several strategies for assigning reference sequences.
As the concerns associated with reference sequence strategies are rather involved, we refer you to the online `wiki documentation`_ for more information.
Output files ------------
This tool produces four output files.
:Hypermutation analysis: CSV file with statistical results. :Hypermutation sites: CSV file with positions of sites and sequences within the alignment suspected of hypermutation. :Hypermutation-positive alignment: FASTA alignment containing only sites suspected of hypermutation. :Hypermutation-negative alignment: FASTA alignment containing only sites not suspected of hypermutation (can be used in downstream phylogenetic/sequence analyses, avoiding the influence of hypermutation on inferences)
Some details about the Hypermutation analysis output ----------------------------------------------------
:sequence: query sequence name :hm_pos: whether the sequence is considered postive for hypermutation at the specified significance level :call_pattern: if a sequence is found to be positive for multiple patterns, this indicates the pattern for which the hypermutation signal (as measured by the MAP value, below) was strongest :cutoff_cdf: roughly speaking, the Bayesian equivalent of a P-value for the hypothesis that there is more G to A mutation in APOBEC associated contexts than in other contexts :map: The Maximum A Posteriori, which can be interpreted as the best estimate of the effect size (relative probability of observing mutations in APOBEC contexts than other contexts) :focus_pos, focus_neg, control_pos, control_neg: G → A mutation (pos) and non G → A mutation (neg; either another mutation or no mutation) counts in the focus (APOBEC-associated) and control contexts
Citation --------
Matsen FA IV, Small CT, Soliven K, Engel GA, Feeroz MM, et al. (2014) `A Novel Bayesian Method for Detection of APOBEC3-Mediated Hypermutation and Its Application to Zoonotic Transmission of Simian Foamy Viruses`_. PLoS Comput Biol 10(2): e1003493. doi:10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003493
